subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] couple of small small texts...
msgSnippet: Thanks so much for this opportunity to practice my Quickscript. I m not a big one for abbreviations, and I did have to do a lot of research to understand
messageBody:
Re: [Read_Alphabet] couple of small small texts...
Thanks so much for this opportunity to practice my Quickscript.

I'm not a big one for abbreviations, and I did have to do a lot of research to understand those.  I think it's a very personal matter, at best.

I don't consider this a "critique" - more like a comment on how the text suggests you pronounce some things, and an attempt to hear your version of Engish in your writing.

I have suggested a few linkages, though, that I find useful.




Hi,

I just tried typing these couple of texts from
Thoreau's 'Walden' during my lunch hour. (Apologies
for any crumbs in the text.)

I've tried using standard contractions wherever I
could remember them - any comments/corrections
gratefully received!

cheers,
Michael




in SPt,  F  Am kanvinsd,  bOT bF fET n bF  eks]Cians,
                                how about eè]Cians ? It saves a stroke!
Ht t mEGtEG  wanself  o  Hs  arT  z  nt a hRdSip bt a pAstFm,
                                          pAs[im  - [i is one of my  most used linkages.
if w liv simpli n wFzli; A H pasVts v H simpla nESanz r
         if this is "pursuits" - and I can't make anything else of it-  pxsMts -  I pronounce the r and I
         don't use a "y"
                        if, as I think that is "simpler", I (an American) would write simplx
stil H s]Pts v H mP RtifiSal. i z nt nesasri Ht a mAn
Sad Dn \z livN bF H swet v \z brQ, anles h swets IzC
        SUd (rhymes with wUd)    swets - see below
Hn Q d.


Qr mAnaz  hv  bG  karaptB bF kamVGjan wi H sEGts. Qr him baks
                                                bUks, rhymes with kUks
risQnd wi a malOdjas kDsN v .goB G indjDN  hm  fP ev...
                   malOdius in American (again no "y")     ev ...- is this "ever"? - I miss the x
... let az fDst b A simpal G wel A .nEcD Qrselvz, dispel
        if az is "us", I would say as or us      QrselvL   dis]el (2 great linkages)
H klQdz c hAN OvD Qr On brQz, n tEk ap a lital lFf
                                litl Read suggests dropping such vowels on p.19
int Qr pPz.


While on the subject of linkage, I would like to propose one to the group.  I am conSTantly writing words with TS in them. I cant desiST in it. FirST, laST, and moST of the time, TS becomes a pain to one who wriTES loTS.

Using the half-T is a start, but what we need is a half-S.  The shape would be like an a question mark upside down and backwards. It might be mistaken for [r, of course, but I see the r as rounder, and the bottom of the s as flatter.

How to type it without ammending everybodies' fonts?  I suggest as a makeshift, we appropriate opt E - that Gaelic LL that seems the wallflower of all the consonants on my keyboard.

Thus swets become swe[È.

Do we have any Welsh members who would object?



Thanks again for the opportunity to hear another English.
--
